title: patch - 90's house music inspired... Lately bass
post_content: Hey allas mentioned in my post yesterday, I just thought i hadn't contributed here for years so sharing this patch FWIW.I decided to focus on FM as most patches I find focus on subtractive.The Nord Lead 2X has a FM implementation that is similar to the 4-OP DX/TX synths. One of the most used in the 90s was the "Lately Bass" patch on the TX81Z (Vogue, What is Love? and lots more)This patch is kindof inspired by that.With FM, one osc modulates the other, so OSC MIX is almost completely OSC1. Try adjusting the Filter Frequency or the FM Amount by tiny amounts, or bring in a bit more of OSC2 for some square wave joy.laterly-bass.mp3laterly-bass.syx(139 Bytes) Downloaded 1645 times

title: RE: how to dial in less vibrato with mod wheel
post_content: I figured it out. Hold down the morph wheel/pedal button while dialing in oscillator modulation LFO amount. I set it to about 1.75. Don't use the morph wheel/pedal button, but do adjust the rate of the LFO using  LFO/ENV knob. I like it around 5.The trick for me was *not* having the vibrato buttons selected for wheel. Evidently, if they are selected, then neither the LFO rate knob, nor oscillator modulation know affect vibrato.

title: RE: Juno Sound for the Nord Lead A1
post_content: Surprised no-one answered yetI don't have a A1 but I do have a Lead 2x and a Juno 106 among others, so I can give a few ideas mainly.Let's just get this out of the way first: you are never going to make an A1 sound just like a Juno. End of. So the question is, how close an approximation can you make, and will you be happy? That's subjective of courseWith that caveat in mind, the approach you need to take is to consider what characteristics the Juno has, and don't stray too far outside of those.- Consider there are two oscs, one saw, one square. You can have either, or both, but don't try anything else like 2 saws. Or, god forbid FM!- The subosc, which you can optionally add in varying degrees.- a lot of characteristic Juno sounds are done using PWM (control the pulse width of a square wave with a slow LFO). Be subtle.- Vintage gear generally has slower envelopes than modern VA, so dial back the attack a little.- Juno shares it's envelope with both the VCA and VCF, so consider that too. Don't use a filter envelope that is wildly different from your amp envelope.- Juno has chorus, and some natural analog slop. Not sure how this is best simulated on the A1, but Unison and detune will help here.Just general things, but maybe a steer in the right direction. Should be possible to make some Juno patches which are quite similar, but the Juno filter characteristics are very hard to copy even in synths that try specifically to do so.You could buy a Deepmind for not much $ and get a lot closer, or pick up a 106 for around £1000 (but you'll spend another big chunk keeping it serviceable over the next decade).There's my 2c. I only come here once or twice a year these days, so i'll probably miss the flame war from all those guys who've never even played a Juno

post_content: Hi profy, sorry for the delay in answering, hope you read thisprofy wrote:brb how i can write bank in nord lead ?   i trying to send sysex but nothing gonna happend ...Page 78 of the Lead2X manual:To receive a Bulk Dump, proceed as follows:1. Connect a cable from MIDI Out on the transmitting device to MIDI IN on the Nord Lead 2X.2. If you are about to receive a complete Bank, you need to scroll to a number in the Bank (Program orPerformance Bank) you want to replace with the received Bank.3. Initiate the transmission on the transmitting device.If the dump contained a complete Bank, it will take the place of the selected Bank in the Nord Lead 2X.If the dump contained one Program/Performance only, this will be put in the “edit buffer” of the activeSlot, instead of the Program/Performance you were playing. However, it is not saved permanently. Tosave it, use Store as described on page 23 and page 35. Note that any Percussion Kits in a Performance,will only be included as “references” when you dump the Performance. If you want to dump PercussionKits including all parameters, you have to be in Program mode!so basically, after connecting your Lead 2X to your PC with a proper software (i use MIDI-OX) and setting the MIDI channels appropriately, you just have to "Send sysex" or the corresponding command on your software.The results will depend if you're in Program or Performance mode, and if you're sending a Program, Percussion Kit, Performance or an entire Bank.If you send a single program (or perc kit or performance) it will not be instantly stored: you will be able to audition it, modify it and if you like it, save it with the normal procedure.But if you send an entire Bank, it will immediately overwrite all the 99 programs in the current bank, so be careful to save your patches before!Also, note that only the first 4 banks of programs and the first bank of performances are overwritable (Program Banks 0-1-2-3, all the Percussion Kits and Performance Bank 0): all the others are fixed, you cannot save anything on those positions.Maybe your problem was that you were trying to save something in an unwritable position?Hope this helps, cheers!

title: Spider program bank for Nord Lead 2X
post_content: Hi everybody!After digging through all the 1400 factory presets of the Lead 2X, I found lots of amazing sounds. The problem is that they're randomly placed among 10 banks with no logic or order and, without a decent screen and without Nord Sound Manager, it's really frustrating to find and use them. It's probably the only aspect in which the iconic 2X is really outdated.So I selected and organized my favourites in a single Program Bank, grouping them in categories so you have all pads together, all basses together etc.I then modified them to my tastes. I especially worked on velocity sensitivity (it's not easy to accurately use velocity on the Lead2X action, so usually I disabled it, or delegated its functions to the Mod Wheel, or used it as an on/off effect) and on using Morph to achieve nice effects, so remember to try out the wheel on most sounds.I wanted to have an easy to use, quick reference bank of general-purpose sounds, so you won't find very quirky experimental stuff in there.Please note I didn't try to accurately replicate acoustic instruments, this is a synth after all! So take the category names (pianos, brasses, strings etc) more as an indication of the generic type of sound.In attachment you have the whole bank in sysex format, and a pdf with the category and names of the 99 sounds.Hope you find it useful, please feel free to give feedback! This is my first "serious" attempt at sound design, so any criticism or comment will be useful.Have fun!

title: NLA1 patch: Respect
post_content: Hej!Tonight I dreamed up a little more complicated patch after listening to Erasures "A Little Respect" (=Vince Clarke) from 1988.Skip the piano part. (I would not mind an OB-6, on the other hand.)The synth part is the interesting bit, and goes a little like this:Respect.mp3Respect.nlas(123 Bytes) Downloaded 256 timesInside a P5P5.jpg (32.76 KiB) Viewed 1547 timesRecipeOsc: square, Pu1 (one more, same pitch), mix 50%, unison 2 (= a little off pitch and fat), mod env 3.0-5.0-3.0Lfo: tri, 5.3, lfo amt 6.1 (on the osc)Filter: LP24, freq 5.0, res 0, kb track 1, mod env amt 7.0Amp: 3.0-5.0-3.0Chorus: 1.5 (can never hurt)Rev: stage1 3.0 ("never leave home without it!")/Michael

title: NLA1 patch; Delayed Reaction
post_content: Hej!Delayed ReactionClassic synth delay techniques from Yaz (= Yazoo in EU)Vince Clarke, the magician and maestro that left Depeche Mode, released the album "Upstairs at Eric's" in 1982. With vocals by the amazing Alison Moyet.Clarke probably used a Pro-One (= Prophet 5 * 1/5) on all of the tracks. One is the funkiest dance track ever: "Situation"!Here I try to make a contemporary version of the patch that was used for the catchy hook ... not nailing it 100%, but ...MIDI sequencing and 808 drum by Logic Pro X;Situation.mp3Delayed Reaction.nlasDelayed Reaction(123 Bytes) Downloaded 320 timesRecipeOsc: square, detune (= dual ocs setting), osc ctrl 0.12 (a tiny, tiny offset), LFO tri 4.0, LFO Amt 1.0 (LFO=just enough for a little warble)Filter: freq 4.0, res 0, Mod Env 4.0, kb track 2/3, drive 2.0 (the env will modulate the cutoff, the overdrive takes me closer to the original = great effect with PWM)Mod Env: A 1.0, D 2.5, R 2.0 (this quickly moves the filter setting)Amp: "on/off" = 0-full-0 (A-D-R)Vibrato: wheel (I did not touch it, but it is there, if you want)Chorus: 3.0 (a must-have, makes the sound much wider)Reverb: stage1 3.0 (I just love this setting)Delay: (I set the mst clk to 118, the tempo of the song) mst clk, tempo 8d, fb 1, wet/dry 2.5, ping-pong (8d sets the delay to 1/8 note, just perfect for this sound and song, like the stereo ping-pong, very Clarke-ish)Test: load the patch, play, turn off the effects, play again ... notice the great difference?/AmicalementMichael in Scania"The Assistant" - my only band member right now!2015-02-17 19.39.14.jpg (155.96 KiB) Viewed 2477 timesRicard: how about the audition for your band?

title: NLA1 patch; (I think I) Found The Funk
post_content: Hej!Last night I was browsing through some promotion videos for the Sub 37, which has interesting features and a nice price, trying to decide if my next kbd will be a Moog.When I over and over again stumbled over the name Bernie Worrell. Who the h*ll is that guy?(I think I) Found The FunkSome research gave me the info that Mr Worrell was one of the fathers of funk! Together with George Clinton he seems to have started both Parliament and Funkadelic = P-funk.Wow! Among their many super hits is "Flashlight" from 1977. (I don' actually really remember all the details of the 70:ies ... I was there but ... chemicals & herbs ...)Mr Worrell really show off how you can funk that MiniMoog (is his one the one with serial no 2?).(A few notes, sloppy, with my French drummer, Mr Arturia. Mr Spark on guitar.)FoundTheFunk.mp3FoundTheFunk.nlasFound The Funk(123 Bytes) Downloaded 332 timesSo, how to dial in that rump-shakin' MiniMoog bass? More research gave me the six commandments;1. The filter - ladder. Named for its sets of paired transistors - is available in most Moogs ... and the NLA1!2. Dirt - the MiniMoog circuitry was far from perfect. Add some distortion to your patch. You got two sources on your NLA1. Use them.3. Square - "it's hip to be" ... you got two square waveforms to mix on your NLA1, add some unison (3) to get more detune.4. Some glide - the Moog is monophonic ... use the glide. You should practice using this a lot if you want to really nail the funk (I never practice).5. Bend over - use the wooden stick. It's much more exact on the NLA1 than the analog Moog. But practice. (Not me.)6. Legato - use it! This adds even more dynamics to your performance.OK, I'm not a funk player ... but these were "facts" I manage to find out. Please comment ...This is Mr Studnitzky of Funk Unit. I go to their concert in Scania every summer. He is ... WOW!FUNK!Sebastian StudnitzkySebastian Studnitzky.jpg (96.54 KiB) Viewed 2417 times/AmicalementMichael in ScaniaThe ladder filter patentUS03475623-1.gif (15.23 KiB) Viewed 2417 times

title: Cool "Rhodes" patch for Lead 2/2X
post_content: Hi!I found this amazing dude on the Tube:Here is his tutorial:GENERAL CONTROL- Start with turning off the LFO I and MOD ENV (they aren’t relevant) turning off by turning Amount knobs to zero– Set LFO II to AMP. Now AMOUNT knob will act as tremolo depth and RATE knob as speed.– Be sure your output is POLY and set the Wheel to affect the filter – It will control brightness.OSCILLATORS- Set OSC I to SINE.– Set OSC II to TRIANGLE, turn on KBD TRACK and tune it exactly like OSC I.– Put the FM on SYNC, so both oscillators will be tuned together, if you wanna try different sound you can put it on SYNC+RING MOD (the FM knob will just go crazy) don’t turn off sync or put it just on ring mod, it will trash your sound.– Turn the MIX knob so it will be around 85% OSC I and 15% OSC II. Pulse width knob is irrelevant since you’re not using any waveform that support it.AMP AND FILTER- Set AMPLIFIER envelope to: Attack = o, Decay= 80%~, Sustain = 0, Release = 0. (Recommended GAIN is 100%)– Set the FILTER TYPE to LP24db, put FREQ knob around 40%, zero RESO, and around 40% ENV AMT with the Velocity Button ON – it will make your sound, sensitive to how hard you play. The stronger you play, the brighter the sound.– Set the FILTER ENV the same as the AMPLIFIER, you may wanna try turning the ATTACK knob up to around 10-20% If you don’t want the sound to be clicky.I tried to follow his directions and it turned out pretty well ...
